When you realize that nothing will change in the leadership, do you tap out and move on or continue trying to be a good leader to your crew who deserves it?
That's definitely a question that requires a little bit more information to give a good answer to.
You know, because what's the situation? Is there an opportunity that you could become the leader long term?

So there's that, I think that you have to assess everything that's going on in the situation which is not evident in this one quick question.
I would say this too, like don't blind side your boss. That's something that if you're going to leave, leave on good terms, explain to what's going on.
Also, that can be an opportunity to start a conversation about how the leadership could improve.

A lot of times people don't want to change anything until it really smacks them in the face and one of the things that smacks them in the face is when one of their good people comes in and says, hey look, I'm going to leave because of these reasons.
And again, you don't on the exit interview or on those conversations, you don't just drop dime and make everyone make it out to be this horrible situation.
Say here's some things that I've noticed. Here's some things that I would want to change. Here's the direction that I see the company going and this is the direction I think it should be going.
And for these reasons, I've decided I'm going to go try, you know, try my hands somewhere else.
I think if you be open like that, it can start some good conversations and possibly you could make some progress or possibly you could confirm.
Your suspicions, which are no one wants to change, no one wants to do anything different. And if that's the case and you realize it's a dead end for you, you got to take that option.
